description: From March 2, 2021, to March 9, 2021, Ghana began its distribution of the AstraZeneca (Covishield) vaccine to the three most affected regions: Greater Accra, Ashanti, and Central Ghana. It prioritized health care workers, front-line workers, adults over 60, and persons with underlying co-morbidities.

"The government of Ghana has imposed a temporary ban on travelers from countries that have recorded 200 or more cases of coronavirus. This ban is however not applicable to Ghanaian citizens or foreigners with valid Ghanaian resident permits.

description: ny passenger arriving in Ghana must be in possession of a negative COVID-19 PCR test result from an accredited laboratory in the country of origin. The test should have been done not more than seventy-two (72) hours before the scheduled departure from the country of origin. All airlines have been instructed to ensure compliance with this directive for all passengers wishing to travel to Ghana, and those airlines who fail in this regard will be duly sanctioned;
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Fellow Ghanaians, it is vital that we protect the lives of our frontline health workers, who are risking their lives every day to battle this virus. That is why Government is placing a high priority on the procurement of personal protective equipment (PPEs) for them. Thus far, three hundred and fifty thousand (350,000) masks, five hundred and fifty eight thousand, six hundred and fifty (558,650) examination gloves, one thousand (1,000) reusable goggles, twenty thousand (20,000) cover-alls, seven thousand (7,000) N-95 respirators, five hundred (500) waterproof gumboots, two thousand (2,000) reusable face shields, two thousand (2,000) gallons of hand sanitizers, ten thousand (10,000) 100ml pieces of hand sanitizers, and five hundred (500) shoe covers have been sent to the regional health directorates, for onward distribution to the district health directorates for use by our health workers in all the districts.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Saturday, March 28, President Nana Akufo-Addo announced a lockdown on the Greater Accra Metropolitan Area and the Greater Kumansi Metropolitan Area from 01:00 (local time) on Monday, March 30, due to the ongoing coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak. According to authorities, all individuals are advised stay at home as much as possible for the next two weeks and will only be permitted to leave their homes for essential items such as food, medicine, and water, or to visit the bank and public toilets
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Greater Accra Metropolitan Area; Greater Kumansi Metropolitan Area.

description:
President of Ghana sets up COVID 19 fund to to receive public donations to help improve the lives of the underprivileged in the country who will be hard-hit by the viral disease.
As a show of commitment, the President has donated his April, May and June salaries as seed capital for the Covid-19 fund.
All Ministers of State and other top appointees at the presidency have also voluntarily decided to donate 50 percent of their salary for the months April, May and June to the COVID-19 Fund.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: establishment of a fund to support the fight against coronavirus

description:
As part of efforts to deal decisively with the coronavirus pandemic, Ghana’s Government has announced some packages to help encourage and motivate front line Health workers involved in the fight against the pandemic to give off their best.

From the package, the health workers in the combat against the covid-19 pandemic will receive 50% percent of their salaries as allowances.

Aside from this, the front line Health workers will also not pay tax on their emoluments for three months, beginning this month to June.
type_text: Government of Ghana announces stimulus package for healthcare workers at the front line of the fight against the corona virus
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The President of the Republic, Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo, admonishes Ghanaians to stop shaking hands completely, and cover their mouths when their cough and sneeze to help prevent the spread of the Coronavirus disease.
He also stated that strict checks are being performed at Ghana's entry  points and isolation treatment centers have been designated in preparation for potential cases. He also mentioned the procurement of extra protective health clothing for health workers being done

President Nana Akufo-Addo has announced that the Ministry of Information will in the coming days provide Ghanaians with weekly updates on the state of the country’s preparedness regarding the outbreak of the deadly coronavirus also known as COVID-19.

description: Individuals who test positive for COVID-19 upon arrival in Ghana, asymptomatic or not, will be required to undergo mandatory quarantine and treatment at a designated health facility or isolation center, for seven (7) days at Government of Ghana expense. All passengers who are in quarantine will undergo a repeat COVID-19 test within 24 hours of arrival, also at Government of Ghana expense.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description:
Ghana, March 15th 2020, Restrictions on mass gathering 
President Nana Akufo-Addo announced a banned on all public gatherings including conferences, workshops, funerals, festivals, church activities and other related events as part of measures to stop the spread of coronavirus in the country. effective from march 15 and will last for four weeks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Religious institutions can now meet with a maximum capacity of 100 participants
In addition to the mandatory wearing of masks for all persons at all times in churches and mosques, a register of names and contact details of all worshippers and hand washing facilities and sanitisers must be provided, with a maximum duration of one (1) hour for each service.
private burials can also be held with a maximum of 100 people

Ghana, March 15th 2020, Restrictions on mass gathering 
President Nana Akufo-Addo announced a banned on all public gatherings including conferences, workshops, funerals, festivals, church activities and other related events as part of measures to stop the spread of coronavirus in the country. effective from march 15 and will last for four weeks. UPDATE: "The original policy announce in march on restrictions on mass gathering has been relaxed, places can reopened with 25% capacity"
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description:
The Ghana Private Road Transport Union (GPRTU) and the Ghana Road Transport Coordinating Council (GRTCC) orders drivers of commercial vehicles to observe social spacing.
By this, three-rowed seating passenger vehicles, including taxis, must now carry not more than two passengers on a row, while those carrying four to five passengers on a row must not exceed three.
